_exec_summary.SummaryText:
UAP Distribution, Inc.
421 Croop
Chester, NE 68327
(402) 324-5771

Updated to provide updated corporate information as well as to include new required RMP information.  UAP Distribution, Inc. is the owner of this facility, having purchased it from Boettcher Enterprises, Inc. and Independent Crop Service.

For further information contact: Dale Buxman, ERS Area Manager, 5701 Eureka Bend, McKinnney, TX 75070 (972) 489-3154, or; Tom Tipton, Location Manager, UAP Distribution, Inc., 421 Croop, Chester, NE 68327 (402) 324-5771.

Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.  The Facility Policy

The owners, management, and employees of UAP Distribution, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire company, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2.  Facility Information - UAP Distribution, Inc. is located at 421 Croop Street,  on the South side of Chester, Nebraska  68327, just East of old U.S. 81 Highway.  (402) 324-5771.  The ammonia storage tank is located on the South side of the access road.

 The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers.

 Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application.

The maximum quantity stored would be 278,000 pounds, composed of 133,000 pounds in our 30,000 gallon storage tank, plus a total  potential of 146,000 pounds in up to 18, 1000 gallon nurse trailers and up to 10, 1500 gallon nurse trailers.
  
Operating procedures for an emergency situation, unloading at a storage facility, and loading of ammonia nurse trailers have been updated as of 03/08/2007.

3.  The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario.

A.  The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of the contents of the 30,000 gallon storage tank,  release

d as a gas over 10 minutes.  The maximum quantity released would be 132,000 pounds, which represents the volume of the largest storage tank(s)  at 85 percent capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 2.50 miles.

B.  The alternative release scenario based on the five-year accident history (or the most likely potential incident is a release from a ruptured hose.  The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 0.47 miles.

4.  The accidental release prevention program.

The facility has implemented most of the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29  CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia".  The governing regulations are put forth by the Nebraska Fire Marshalls Office and the facility is inspected on a regular basis by company personnel, inspectors from the State of Nebraska, and representatives of the Company's insurance carrier.  

5.  The Five-year Accident History 

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor  to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
   
6.  The emergency response program.

 The facility has:

a.  a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR1910.38; a copy of the plan has been provided to local authorities.

b.  provided a copy of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) to local authorities.

c.  provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

7.  Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-go

ing process at the facility.  At least annually,  evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional, specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.  Training is on-going and accomplished through a combination of in-company, seminars, use of videos, and site-specific analysis.
